item.title: About Me
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: Hi, I'm Joshua. I'm a final year science undergrad at the University of Sheffield. I'm a fan of writing, photography, filmmaking, design and Scandinavia. You can contact me at joshua.hackett93@gmail.com or on Twitter.

item.title: No, cinema is not dying
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded:
While we should welcome any business that hopes to make the neglected George Street a valuable part of the city again, the new arthouse cinema currently under construction in our fair city has attracted concern, particularly over what it means for the much-loved Showroom. [caption id="attachment_28" align="alignright" width="379"] Sheffield's beloved Showroom.[/caption] There are some who say that competition between cinemas is akin to rearranging the deck chairs on the Titanic; that the winner will be the ephemeral leader of a market that is shrinking out of significance in the face of competition from streaming websites. This is not a new worry. Back in the 1970s and 80s, the Motion Picture Association of America were terrified of a strange new invention; the video cassette. MPAA chairperson Jack Valenti famously opined; “The VCR is to the film producer as the Boston strangler is to the woman home alone.” Colourful metaphor aside, his argument is still trotted out today, with the VCR replaced by a string of more modern inventions; DVD, Blu-ray, Netflix. This argument may well have some validity, but it is certainly overstated. An analogy: gourmet restaurants did not go away when McDonalds came on the scene, even though the latter was undoubtedly faster and cheaper. Why? Because the posh restaurants (the cinemas) offer an experience above and beyond what fast food (the streaming sites) can hope to compete with. Not too long ago, authors and readers alike were fearful that the Kindle and its digital ilk meant an end for the printed word. While ebooks are eating up a particular part of the market – specifically mass market paperbacks (the “fast food” of the literary industry – think Fifty Shades of Grey), hardback sales are gloriously unaffected. The Showroom has a great strategy; they curate a community, putting on special events, socials and festivals all designed to bring people together over their love of film. Loyal patrons are thus sculpted. This sense of community and curated experience is impossible to find through a browser window. Curzon’s planned cinema will encompass a roof terrace for open-air screenings. Again, streaming sites can’t compete with this kind of bespoke experience:

Chairs! All picked out by Jon and Nigel, these. The only cookie cutters @CurzonSheffield are in the kitchen. pic.twitter.com/ECQSpqjAh6

— Curzon Sheffield (@CurzonSheffield) January 12, 2015

The days when cinemas monopolised the movie-watching experience may be gone, but demand for the bespoke “gourmet” experience remains. Other cinemas must follow the Showroom’s example; rethink themselves, and become experts at meeting this demand. A second indie cinema on our doorstep is a significant step in the right direction. This article originally appeared in Forge Press in November 2014.

item.title: Review: Bellowhead at Sheffield City Hall
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_20" align="alignleft" width="647"] Bellowhead on stage. CC image courtesy of Flickr user Stuart Madely.[/caption] There aren’t many things that can bring Sheffield’s middle-aged, middle-class population together into the same room. Bellowhead is one of them. This is a bit ironic, given folk’s working class roots. It’s the kind of audience where you don’t have to look hard to find someone who thinks it’s all a bit noisy, and wishes everyone else would just sit back down so they can see the show. Arguably the biggest folk band in the world, in terms of both popularity and members, Bellowhead have also won numerous accolades for their dynamic live shows. The stage is a multi-leveled construction intended to keep as many of the band’s eleven members visible at once. They’ve even incorporated a sofa, to which members of the brass section periodically retire to between tunes. One wonders how they managed to fit everyone on stage back when their popularity didn’t yet justify such large venues. Seated shows aren’t conducive to the audience participation that the band thrives on – moving every ten minutes so someone who’s had one too many overpriced glasses of wine can relieve themselves gets old. This, plus the decision to base the setlist heavily on new album Revival, meant that for the majority of the show, the audience weren’t as attuned to the band’s energy as they could have been. But just as you think Bellowhead have misjudged their crowd, they bring out the old classics London Town and New York Girls, which get virtually the whole demographically advanced audience to their feet. Other highlights include uniquely haunting renditions of Captain Wedderbaum and Greenwod Side. This is not a perfect show, but it’s about as good as clean, staunchly middle class entertainment gets. You can also take it as a neat illustration of the class divide in modern Britain, if so inclined.

Bellowhead at Sheffield City Hall last night #bellowhead #sheffield #concert #blackandwhite @Bellowhead pic.twitter.com/x6uwKvWTT8

— Lord Croker (@LordCroker) November 9, 2014
This review originally appeared in Forge Press in November 2014.

item.title: Review: Mogwai at MAGNA
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_26" align="alignleft" width="633"] Magna's red wall.[/caption] You leave the train at Meadowhall. You walk along poorly lit canals and through a trading estate to arrive at Magna. This is not your average venue. The expansive former steelworks looks menacing at night, reminiscent of a spacecraft about to take off. You feel like a pilgrim. Perhaps this is what the band intended. The industrial setting is certainly appropriate. You enter, and are shepherded into a room of fans. Tables and chairs permit only cabaret-style queuing. The sole light source is a healthy red glow emitted from one wall. This is surreal, to say the least. Eventually, you are allowed into a cavernous room in the bowels of Magna. Support act RM Hubbart does more than one man and an acoustic guitar should ever be expected to. He spends more time telling anecdotes about the Scottish referendum and Buckstasy – ecstasy and wine – than playing music, but it doesn’t feel out of place. His humour is endearing and the music both memorable and surprisingly diverse. A brief soundcheck later – no small feat, given the number of guitars their layered sound demands – and Mogwai are on stage. The band’s love of quiet/loud dynamic contrast in their music is well-known, and a live setting does it justice, allowing great barrages of sound.
@mogwaiband = ears ringing with joy! Ace to see the Sheffield crew in attendance @thenorth pic.twitter.com/6YfOvpi4Rp — Sara Hill (@Sara_Hill_) October 23, 2014
Highlights include a weighty performance of new track Remurdered, and the aggressive closer Batcat, where one unfortunate member of an otherwise calm audience tumbled over the barrier and faceplanted on the other side. If there are flaws with the show, they are in the band’s engagement with the audience, or lack thereof. At this stage in Mogwai’s career, having survived the rise and fall of their own post-rock genre, this is unlikely to change. Shows in venues like this are gambles, but this one appears to have paid off. This review originally appeared in Forge Press.

item.title: News: Campus crime plunges to new low
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_37" align="alignleft" width="653"] CC image courtesy of Flickr user Ray Forster.[/caption] Crime on campus has reached an all-time low, according to figures released last week. Only 159 incidents were reported in the last academic year (2014/14). This is a halving of figures reported four years ago. The university credited strong partnership with South Yorkshire Police for the decline. The news coincided with annual Crime Prevention Week, which sees representatives from South Yorkshire Police and university security teams set up information stands on campus, in order to share advice on avoiding becoming a victim of crime and give out free property marking kits. Richard Yates, head of Security Services, said; “the reduction of student burglary is one of our key priorities.” Burglaries in student-heavy areas are a recurring problem. So far in 2014, 189 burglaries have been reported in Broomhill and 135 in Crookes, according to police statistics. On a string of five burglaries which occurred in Crookes last year, Detective Inspector Richard Partridge said; “In these five cases, the offences were easily preventable. All that the opportunist offenders had to do was walk in and help themselves.” That same advice is being echoed today. PC Tom Goodhill, the new police liaison officer for the university, noted; “Thieves and burglars like ‘easy’ targets. Simple things like closing your windows and locking your doors are a good start.” Becca Goldberg, a third year biology student whose house was burgled last September, notes; “Don’t leave valuables when you know there won’t be any people staying in the house.” Sheffield has a reputation as one of the safer university cities. According to data from the Complete University Guide, the safest campuses include Durham, Winchester and Aberystwyth. Topping the list is the privately-run Buckingham University. London universities are among the least safe, along with Manchester and Leeds. Sheffield itself is halfway between these extremes. This article initially appeared in Forge Press in November 2014.

item.title: Review: Sheffield v Leeds Poetry Slam
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_51" align="alignnone" width="655"] Leeds student Emma Ward on stage.[/caption] Ten young poets gather in the depths of Sheffield’s student union. Five have journeyed from Leeds and five are on their home turf. An audience in the triple digits takes their seats. There are two rounds, separated by an intermission. Performances are scored by judges in the audience, and the best-scoring return for the second round. As is traditional, the audience snaps their fingers in lieu of clapping, so as not to disrupt the flow of words. To a newcomer, the lack of applause is eerie – and those little finger snaps feel very powerful indeed. A fantastic standard of poetry abounds from both teams (only 1.4 points stood between the Leeds team and victory), with subject matter ranging from family to rape culture, from body image to Disney. Some bring notebooks; some recite their work from memory. There are flaws, of course – false starts, forgotten lines, but it’s all part of the experience. The slam feels lo-fi; unembellished and genuine. The material performed is engaging, diverse and most importantly, heartfelt on the part of every competitor. Highlight performances include Leeds student Emma Ward, whose delivery and stage presence stood out amongst the other competitors, and Greer Dewdney of Sheffield, whose initial poem presented some of the most arresting imagery of the evening. Both received a generous share of finger snaps. Rhys Dumont of the Sheffield Open Mic society was on great form, providing acoustic tunes during the intermission. Miriam Schechter, social secretary of Sheffield Poetry Society, said of the occasion; “The event went great. All the poets were top notch. Especially the haikus.” There is no shortage of memorable lines, but it can be argued that the audience provides the line of the night, with; “This is my first poetry slam.” Asking around, it becomes clear that a considerable fraction have never considered attending something like this before.

Massive thanks to everyone who came to our slam last night and to the poets from Shef and @LUSpokenWord who put on a spectacular viewing

— UoS Poetry Society (@ShefPoetrySoc) November 10, 2014
For people whose last exposure to poetry may have been at A-level or even GCSE, evenings like this one serve as valuable reintroductions to the artform. More than a few new converts are certainly gained tonight. The poetry society plans more slams in future. As we inexorably approach another exam period, if you find yourself disillusioned or weighed down by work, go and see one of them between stints at the IC – you won’t be disappointed. 5/5 This review originally appeared in Forge Press in November 2014.

item.title: Review: Editors at O2 Academy Birmingham
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_55" align="alignright" width="217"] Tom Smith on stage. CC image courtesy of Flickr user Luigi Orru[/caption] Midlands post-punk five-piece Editors returned to their local roots this Saturday with a fine set at the O2 Academy Birmingham. Preceded by competent but forgettable opener British Sea Power, Editors took to a sparsely furnished stage at nine. Opening with the whopping new song Sugar, Editors played material from all four of their albums, including a good number of fan favourites. Clad in trademark skinny jeans and black t-shirt, frontman Tom Smith’s stage persona could be likened to that of a hyperactive child. That is no bad thing; his energy and enthusiasm are infectious, and his arcane gestures and dance moves form a memorable part of the band’s shows for fans and the uninitiated alike. You would be forgiven for thinking the band were a three-piece, such was the smoke obscuring rear guard Elliot Williams (keys) and Ed Lay (drums). In the second half, the smoke cleared some and Elliot made a welcome trip to the front, guitar in hand, while Smith managed the piano. His sudden appearance no doubt took some less observant audience members by surprise. The scant adornment of the stage was balanced by mostly well-executed, clean lighting choices and heavy use of strobes. The crowning moment of the performance was the upbeat whole-band version of Nothing, midway through a three-song encore; a triumphal statement that that despite a tough few years; the difficult departure of founding member Chris Urbanowitz and two new faces, the band has revitalised. Smith and company still have what it takes to make solid albums and deliver live. This review originally appeared in Forge Press in November 2013.

item.title: News: Lib Dems defend Uni Arms
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_60" align="alignright" width="198"] CC image courtesy of Flickr user Pete Green[/caption] Local Liberal Democrats have handed in their petition to the University of Sheffield, which asks that the University Arms be protected from demolition. The petition gathered over 1700 signatures. The Campus Masterplan, which closed for consultation on Tuesday 14th October, is a 109-page document setting out a decade of improvement works, including new green spaces, pedestrianised streets, cycle hubs and new buildings. One option presented in the document involves the demolition of the University Arms, replaced by a new Faculty of Science building. The Arms, which was refurbished this summer, has catered to the general public since 2007, having previously operated as Club 197 the staff club for the University. It is known particularly for its selection of locally brewed real ales. Harry Matthews, Liberal Democrat candidate for Crookes, said; “The University says that they wanted the public to respond - and they have. It is clear that University must not proceed with their proposal to demolish the University Arms.” In an interview with Forge TV, Matthews continued; “The plans put forward don’t include replacing it with anything, so we’d see a net loss of social space.” [youtube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LmqFes-DwPY] On the unique atmosphere of the pub, which has historically been most popular with postgraduates and staff, Matthews said; “It’s so distinct from anything else on campus – it’s not like Interval, it’s not like Bar One.” Matthews hopes that the University will take the petition to heart, but plans to try and have the Arms listed as an “asset of community value” if the University pushes forward with the existing proposal. Such a listing would add additional regulatory hurdles to any demolition process. Marcus Foster, co-chair of Sheffield Liberal Youth, said; “Demolition would be a big loss to staff, students and residents." This article originally appeared in Forge Press in October 2014.

item.title: Review: Remember Me, Episode 1
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: The BBC’s contemporary ghost story Remember Me is intriguing from the outset. A evocative scene, played in reverse, shows us waves on Scarborough beach lapping against an anonymous human form covered in cloth, which precedes to rise off the sand and, apparently, return to life. Michael Palin’s return to acting is certainly the series’ biggest selling point. The Broomhill native’s portrayal of lead character Tom Parfitt is equal parts amiable, mysterious and jittery. Jodie Comer plays Hannah, a teenage care assistant at the home where Parfitt comes to live. While some of her decisions in this episode would have a genre-savvy viewer shaking their head, her character is certainly the most interesting thus far. [youtube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tUOWxURuLUc&w=560&h=315] The cinematography is nicely stylized - infused with shots of a foreboding, desolate and seemingly depopulated Yorkshire. Artsy camera angles are used to great effect in conveying the sense of the unnatural that goes along with whatever spectre is following Tom Parfitt around. Filmed in Huddersfield and Scarborough, but set in an indeterminate part of God’s own county, the show is infused with a heavy sense of place, which should please northerners. The soundtrack is suitably haunting, centred on a minimalist rendition of the classic folk song Scarborough Fair. Less well executed is the pacing of this first episode. It serves mostly to introduce cast members, with only a single major plot development occurring over the hour. Scenes with Mark Addy’s unambitious police sergeant Rob Fairholme felt particularly extraneous, but we can presume that this setup will pay off later on. One can’t help but feel that more could have been accomplished with this first episode, plotwise. After a lot of time spent cultivating a subtle, chilly atmosphere, the final minutes of the episode hinted at resorting to a more overt form of horror. It would be a shame if, like so many of its predecessors, Remember Me took the easy way out and resorted to cheap jump scares. Until the last fifteen minutes, it isn’t clear whether Remember Me is pitching itself as a character-driven drama or a horror. The appearance of a haunted rocking chair and a creepy attic settles the question in favour of the latter. If we’re being stern, there isn’t much here that hasn’t been seen before. That said, Remember Me is nonetheless worth watching, and will surely improve as we get into the meat of the storyline. 4/5 This review initially appeared in Forge Press in December 2014.

item.title: Is Spotify the future?
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: Spotify users whose music tastes tend toward mainstream pop will have recently noticed a conspicuous gap in their playlists. Taylor Swift’s catalogue is, as of this month, absent. [caption id="attachment_97" align="alignright" width="243"] Daniel Ek, Spotify CEO. CC image courtesy of Wikimedia Commons user Seth Whales.[/caption] She cited a lack of fair compensation, having earned “only” half a million dollars in the last year. Daniel Ek, Spotify founder, took issue with Swift’s sums, and argued that Spotify protects artists from illegal downloading, which earns them nothing. Ironically, Ek is the former CEO of uTorrent; one of the most prolific torrenting apps and a thorn in the side of every major record company. If Swift is complaining about half a million in earnings, she should spare a thought for the smaller indie artists on Spotify, who earn a comparative pittance. Something needs to change. Asked about the controversy, NME’s godlike genius Dave Grohl went on record saying; “I don’t fucking care”, before bemoaning the way things used to be, when the biggest barrier to new artists was getting heard, and when live performances shouldered the money-making burden. Should Spotify be treated purely as a marketing tool for gigs? It’s true that ticket sales are experiencing a surge in growth as record sales continue to shrink. But what about the Portisheads and Kate Bushes of the world – the artists who don’t or can’t perform live? Author and digital sage Cory Doctorow suggests a return to the patronage model. Just as the pope commissioned Michaelangelo to paint the Sistine Chapel, contemporary artists may have to solicit funding from fans. [caption id="attachment_98" align="alignright" width="300"] Amanda Palmer live in 2008. CC image courtesy of Wikimedia Commons user Jayen466.[/caption] Some musicians are already taking this to heart. Amanda Palmer successfully crowdfunded one million dollars via Kickstarter to create her 2012 album Theatre is Evil, which was then given away under a “pay what you want” arrangement. The website Patreon, which allows fans to directly support creative sorts with their wallets, boasts a cash throughput of over one million dollars per month. Considering the site is less than two years old, this is a considerable achievement. Not everyone is supportive. Nine Inch Nails’ Trent Reznor accuses patronage of devaluing music, saying “I made my album as well as I could, and it costs ten bucks, or go fuck yourself.” Whether the future is streaming, patronage or something else, it’s clear that the recording industry is undergoing a paradigm shift. Since Spotify is clearly positioning itself as the new paradigm; it’s a good thing that Swift has attracted scrutiny to their business practices. This article originally appeared in Forge Press in November 2014.

item.title: News: Smart new urban renewal prospect for Sheffield
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded:
A unique urban park is planned in a neglected region of Sheffield. The park, to be known as Love Square, will be located in the Riverside district, to the northeast of the city centre, less than half an hour from campus. The park is intended to become a new social hub for the community. It is planned to include a café made from reclaimed shipping containers, wildflower meadows, lawns, a mini wetland, artworks, and will incorporate “native plants and wildlife in exciting ways”. Volunteers, especially students and other young people, will be sought to help construct and maintain the park – gaining an understanding of sustainable gardening in return. [youtube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5kwipKgvuUk] Professor Nigel Dunnet, one of the project’s leaders, says; “Love Square will do so many different things for so many different people.” Dunnet’s planting design expertise was previously used to great effect at London’s Olympic Park. Simon Ogden, of Sheffield City Council, says of the project; “There are sites like this all over the city. We want to demonstrate that they can have a positive impact on their surroundings. The Riverside district was formerly a thriving community, but has suffered from decades of dereliction and economic disinterest. The location neighbours a road where additional development is planned as part of the Council’s £3.6 million “grey to green” urban renewal scheme – trees and native plants will be used to create an “eco-corridor” adjoining Love Square. The proposal is backed by Sheffield City council, the University, and numerous charities and businesses including Autism Plus and the Creative Arts Development Space. Love Square is currently seeking £12,000 of funding from the Grow Wild campaign, going up against four similar projects nationwide. Voting closes on the 4th November.
Vote for Love Square and help us win the #GrowWild England Flagship and create a new urban nature park in Sheffield http://t.co/UGhowabJQ7 — Love Square (@lovesquare_shef) October 7, 2014
 This article was written in October 2014.

item.title: News: Uni praised as top inclusive employer
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded:
The University of Sheffield has achieved 43rd place in this year’s Stonewall Workplace Equality Index, which recognises the country’s top 100 LGBT-friendly employers. According to Stonewall, the Index “recognises efforts to tackle discrimination and to create an inclusive workplace for LGBT employees”. Criteria for a high ranking includes staff training covering sexual orientation and gender identities, along with support of local community events such as Pride. The news comes on the heels of 2014’s staff survey, which revealed 98% of respondents agreed that the University “respects staff regardless of sexual orientation”.

Proud to be recognised as one of the UK’s most inclusive employers for LGB staff in the @stonewalluk Equality Index http://t.co/8ijc69sMWH

— Sheffield University (@sheffielduni) January 14, 2015
The University has steadily risen through the index in recent years, ranked 83rd last year and failing to make the top 100 in 2013. Andrew Dodman, HR director, said “to have improved so much is testimony to our ongoing and sustained commitment to equality and diversity”. In an online statement, the University credited a number of recent awards for the ranking, including a Chamber of Commons Diversity Award and a Stonewall Best Practice & Innovation in Community Engagement Award. Back in June, the rainbow flag flew outside Firth Court, coinciding with Sheffield Pride for the second year running. This year, the University plans to encourage more staff to disclose sexual orientation on equal opportunities forms, and to push forward with their Open@TUoS project, which aims to encourage LGBT allies within the university. [youtube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0LSNDbRQa3g&w=560&h=315] The University plans to recognise LGBT history month by hosting a photo exhibition, showcasing work by professional and amateur photographers celebrating LGBT life in the city. The exhibition will run in late February. This article originally appeared in Forge Press in January 2015.

item.title: Review: Mad City
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded:
I watched Mad City last night.
If you've not seen it, it's a 1997 thriller, where disgruntled museum security guard Sam Baily (John Travolta) accidentally creates a hostage situation with a shotgun and a bag of dynamite. Dustin Hoffman plays a washed-up television newsman who, purely by chance, is inside the museum at the time.
Hoffman's character proceeds to make a story out of the situation, interviewing Baily live on TV. A media circus ensues, as teams of rival reporters craft incompatible narratives about Baily. Eventually, with any hope of avoiding prison destroyed by a succession of television exposés, Baily commits suicide, explosively.
[youtube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NA40equCdKo]
As a viewer in 2015, the whole movie feels dated, and not only because of the young visages of the two lead characters. There is, of course, no Twitter, no internet, not even a mobile phone to be seen.
There's a scene I particularly liked, where a young reporter exchanges a few seemingly heartfelt words with the hostage-taker's mother, before we pan across to see a camera operator standing several feet away, revealing the whole thing to be staged for the 6'o'clock news.
In another scene, two children leave the museum , only to be rushed by a tsunami of reporters and camera operators jumping over the police lines. The audience almost expects the kids to turn tail and run back inside to the relative safety of the man with the shotgun.
The satire may be a little obvious and hamfisted, but there's a refreshing simplicity in a film that knows what it wants to say, and just says it. It conveys a worry that the news cycle was becoming too fast, at the expense of facts and objectivity.
If there was any truth to that worry back in 1997, then there is more truth to it today. Nowadays, the cameras are much smaller, the news cycle is faster, the competition to get news out is greater and the audience is mostly online. Plus, through social media, the audience does not need to accept the narrative presented to them. They have a platform to build their own stories and run with them.
While Mad City is not a work of great art, it is a nice reminder that concerns about media manipulation are hardly a new phenomenon.

item.title: Sheffield's Most Fascinating Research Projects
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded:
The most recent Research Excellence Framework, published last month, picked out Sheffield as one of the top ten universities in the country for research. The REF identifies institutions which consistently produce a large volume of high-quality research in a wide range of subjects.
So proud that #REF2014 confirms our global reputation for research that makes a difference http://t.co/teMzJFOxNE pic.twitter.com/HxjQV5eIe6 — Sheffield University (@sheffielduni) December 18, 2014
So what is this research? Let’s take a look at six of the most interesting, ground-breaking or simply bizarre projects university staff are involved in when they aren’t giving lectures. In no particular order, they are; Boulby Mine At 1100 metres deep, it’s the furthest underground one can get without crossing the English Channel. Aside from being a working mine, Boulby houses a unique laboratory studying cosmic rays, dark matter, radioactivity and even the possibility of alien life. The laboratory’s unique position is necessary to isolate the experiments from the background radiation; beneath a kilometre of rock, all but the most powerful radiation will be absent, leaving researchers in no doubt what their experiments detect. DNA GPS Dr Eran Elhaik can find out where you live from a blood sample, assuming your ancestors haven’t moved in a thousand years. His new technique, developed in partnership with scientists in California, uses DNA to pinpoint where one’s ancestors originate. On the island of Sardinia, where families rarely move around, the technique accurately places nearly everyone within 50km of their home village, using only DNA. Dr Elhaik hopes the technique will help orphans explore their ancestry, along with helping to personalise drug therapies to particular patient groups for better results. [youtube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Aap-s1kle4Q] Computer-generated humans The Insigneo Institute is simulating the human body in software, with the aid of data collected from labs and hospitals worldwide. They hope that their virtual model will let us better predict how patients will respond to therapies, without putting any real human beings at risk. Ethical machines As robots are introduced to more and more areas of society, they will need strong codes of behaviour governing what they do in awkward situations. Inspired by Asimov’s famous laws of robotics, a group of Sheffield researchers is working on this very problem. Professor Sandor Veres, of the Department of Automatic Control and Systems Engineering, says that now self-driving cars are on the horizon, the work is vital; “an autonomous car might have to choose between two bad decisions: hit a car cutting across the street unexpectedly, or braking suddenly so that the car behind can’t stop.” The project is being conducted in partnership with Liverpool and Bristol universities. [caption id="attachment_133" align="alignright" width="300"] Today's 3D printers work mainly with plastic resin. CC image courtesy of Subhashish Panigrahi.[/caption] AdAM’s 3D Printers While today’s 3D printers work mostly with plastic, the Centre for Advanced Additive Manufacturing hopes to introduce them to all areas of industry, producing cheap, personalised prosthetics and more efficient machine parts. Festival of the Mind While not strictly a research project, the festival, which occurred for the second time in September, is certainly ground-breaking in the way it communicates what the university does to the residents of the city. Centred around a 1920s cabaret spiegeltent in Barker’s Pool and a reopened Castle House – the disused department store in the city centre – the festival paired researchers with artists to communicate their work with the public. Meeting with very positive feedback, the Festival will surely be reappearing in years to come.

item.title: 800px-Printing_with_a_3D_printer_at_Makers_Party_Bangalore_2013_11
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.excerpt:encoded: Today's 3D printers work mainly with plastic resin, but AdAM's researchers have high hopes for the technology. CC image courtesy of Subhashish Panigrahi.

item.title: 800px-Acceptance_speech_Peter_Watts
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.excerpt:encoded: Peter Watts. CC image courtesy of Wikimedia Commons user Johan A.

item.title: Review: Blindsight
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: Blindsight is a philosophical think-piece packaged in sci-fi horror. Named for the phenomenon of blind people somehow still being able to sense their surroundings, it claims to be a story about first contact with aliens, but the aliens turn out to be stranger than anything we could have imagined. The core proposal of the novel is that consciousness is not only an illusion, but actually a hindrance to getting things done. Through a compelling cast of misfits, including a man who has had half of his brain replaced with a computer and a woman with four distinct personalities in one body, Watts actually has you believing this premise by the last chapter; consigned to his cynical worldview. The passages in which our brave protagonists explore an alien artefact on the edge of a solar system are particularly unsettling. While the ideas it presents offer its worst scares, Blindsight does have monsters in the old-fashioned sense; bizzare, many-armed creatures that turn out to be little more than biological robots, blindly following programming like cells in a body. Oh, and vampires. But there are no sparkles or love triangles here. Watt’s vampires are viscerally terrifying predators – an ancient cannibalistic sub-species of humans brought back into the world through genetic tinkering. His scientific explanation for their aversion to crosses is especially memorable; a form of epilepsy, triggered by right-angled shapes. [caption id="attachment_138" align="alignright" width="264"] Peter Watts. CC image courtesy of Wikimedia Commons user Johan A.[/caption] Watts’ continues the tradition of science fiction authors who err on the side of scientific plausibility – he trained as a marine biologist, after all – and the story is better for it. There are no bumpy-headed Star Trek-esque aliens or quick, easy journeys between planets to be found in this book. Space travel is slow, difficult and expensive, just as in the real world. The scientific plausibility lends the book an unsettling relevance to our own world. The uncomfortable ideas Watts presents are all founded in real science and philosophy; this alone makes the book scarier than most horrors a reader will come across. Now available as a free ebook on the author’s website, this is not an easy or comfortable read, but it is certainly an engaging one, and continues to play on the mind long after the final page.

item.title: Finding a photographic voice
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: Photography is my main hobby. I've been into it to some extent for nearly five years now, but it's only during the last two that I'd say I've started to produce work that I'm actually proud of. A photographer, like any artist, has a personal voice. They have particular subjects that interest them, and a particular style that differentiates their work from that of others, even if the subject is the same. So what is my "voice"? Economy. It's said that photographers, as a general rule, should eliminate distractions, but my favourite work takes this to an extreme, cutting down the composition to a few key elements. I'm a big fan of Michael Kenna, a landscape photographer who often uses extremely long exposures to smooth out motion and remove extraneous details. The bare minimum often makes a stronger image. Geometry. This often goes hand-in hand with economy and the use of black and white. These two things will tend to make the basic shapes making up an image more obvious. I'll look for parallel lines, leading lines and pleasing shapes. Mystery. The work I'm most proud of takes something everyday and adds an air of mystery to it. Less is more. This goes hand-in-hand with economy. Black and white. I find that unless my photos have a strong combination of colours that mix well together, the final product is often better served by taking the colour out completely. It's just another way of purging distractions from the composition. Analogue formats. Like most modern photographers, I learned on digital, but increasingly, my favourite work comes from film. Without a screen, you can't obsess over the images you've just taken, so you spend more time finding the next one. You don't have to worry about ISO, autofocus, white balance or any of the other settings a modern digital camera offers. I was unsure at first, but now I find the simplicity of film reassuring.

item.title: Review: Ex Machina
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: Ex Machina is a tale of a young coder, Caleb (Domhnall Gleeson), who ostensibly wins a lottery and a chance to meet Nathan (Oscar Isaac), the CEO of the company he works for. It quickly becomes apparent that Caleb has actually been recruited to test Nathan’s latest creation; an artificially intelligent machine called Ava (Alicia Vikander). [youtube=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sNExF5WYMaA] In the claustrophobic, spartan interiors of Nathan's underground complex, Caleb becomes quite taken with Ava, but her latent sexuality initially distresses him. The overt femininity of female androids (more properly, gynoids) in other works of fiction is often taken as read, but here it’s the crux of the film. In an early scene, Nathan poses a question; is there anything that is intelligent that lacks a sexual dimension? It becomes clear that Caleb is being manipulated, but by whom? Nathan’s “brogrammer” character is a jab at Silicon Valley’s famous gender gap, and poses an interesting question about the kind of people we want creating artificial intelligence. His character can also be taken as a veiled assault on lazy, almost always male, science fiction writers, and their collective love affair with sexy female robots. Bluebook, Nathan’s company, is a thinly disguised Facebook/Google stand-in and a nod to Google’s own adventures in robotics, ranging from their autonomous cars to their purchase of Boston Dynamics. In one scene, Nathan admits that information harvested from the world’s smartphones went into building Ava’s mind – a neat post-Snowden addition. Alicia Vikander’s experience as a ballerina is used to great effect; her performance as Ava is delicately perched halfway between human and machine. Her scene with Nathan at the film’s climax looks like a deftly choreographed dance. Ex Machina should be commended for not giving into an obvious twist; but nonetheless playing with the possibility in the film’s bloodiest scene. The conclusion can be read as intensely feminist, for reasons difficult to elaborate on without spoilers, and brings to mind the film’s tagline; “there is nothing more human than the will to survive”. For older works of the genre, like Terminator, or Star Trek, artificial intelligence seemed like a hazy, far-off topic. Now, in the age of mass surveillance, voice-activated assistants in our smartphones, yearly doublings in computing power and seemingly weekly warnings from Stephen Hawking about the dangers of AI, it seems much more immediate. Science fiction has never been about the future. It has always been about the present. In line with the finest works of the genre, Ex Machina succeeds in exploring our present worries about surveillance, robotics and gender politics. This film is refreshing, current and intelligent.

item.title: Review: 2312
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: I went into 2312 expecting a similar read to David Brin's recent magnum opus Existence. The environmental themes of the book were well-founded, and the world-building generally strong. The mechanism of sprinkling extracts throughout the book is a good solution to the exposition problem imposed by such novel settings. It is far preferable to putting such exposition in the mouths of characters, or worse, integrating it into normal paragraphs at the expense of pace. It also gives Robinson license to delve deeply into matters on which the plot does not depend, but will surely be of interest to readers. Robinson's "terrarium" concept is another iteration of the space habitats currently in vogue in science fiction, most recently seen on screen at the climax of Nolan's Interstellar. Here, asteroids are hollowed out by self-replicating robot excavators, spun for gravity, an interior landscape sculpted and a natural biome seeded. They are self-contained, inside-out artificial worlds. From a scientific perspective, this approach is likely to prove the most fruitful way of creating such things in reality, being much less expensive than creating such a habitat from scratch. On the topic of pacing, the book habitually moves through things quickly, from scene to scene, without so much stopping to establish a mood. While the settings are richly imagined and described, they are only rare points in the book where these richly imagined settings are imbued with emotional context, due to the speed at which characters move through them. Robinson's economic vision for this world, of a planned economy for the necessities (modelled after the real-world Mondragon corporation) while late-stage capitalism continues to thrive on the fringes, is not as revolutionary as readers of left-wing sci-fi may be used to. For readers accustomed to the anarcho-socialist leanings of the Iain Banks' Culture, for instance, this will seem positively near-future by comparison. The secondary characters are underdeveloped. Protagonist Swan's anguish at the recent passing of grandmother Alex is understandable and well-expressed, but nonetheless starts to wear on the reader, and impacts Swan's likeability. The queer themes are also a welcome addition. 2312 is massive in scope, imaginative, but is weighed down by flaws.

item.title: Review: Citizenfour
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: Between 2012 and 2013, the journalist Glenn Greenwald and filmmaker Laura Poitras began recieving emails from a mysterious NSA whistleblower. These conversations culminated in the largest surveillance program in US history being revealed to the public. [youtube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XiGwAvd5mvM] This story is now familiar to most of us, and it is probably for this reason that Poitras’ Citizenfour does not delve deeply into the content of the leaks themselves. The film is instead an intimate character portrait of Snowden; his reasons for leaking the files and his worries about government power, as revealed through conversations with Greenwald and the Guardian’s Ewan McAskill. The bulk of Citizenfour is footage recorded in Snowden’s Hong Kong hotel room in the days leading up to publication. We see his subtle paranoia, overlaid with apparent calm. This film cuts through the diverse political opinions of Snowden, showing him to be essentially a normal person; not a malcontent, not an anarchist, nor any of the other things he was accused of being. We see the context behind the single, famous image of Snowden that adorned countless news articles and comment pieces. The film is contemplative and slow paced, as if paying respect to the seriousness of its topic. The camera remains dispassionate, perhaps attempting to escape the politicised, almost dichotomous opinions surrounding this man. While deliberately light on the technical details, the film does at least address the "metadata defence"; a common catchphrase among government officials in the days following the leaks. "We don't collect content", the argument goes, "only metadata"; Citizenfour concisely explains how overlapping streams of metadata are no less revealing than content itself. As two points in the film is explicit reference made to UK's role in the spying. The NSA loves GCHQ's program, says Snowden in a text exchange, because it goes further than is permitted in the US, and they’re allowed to "query it all day long". Citizenfour is dedicated to “those who make great sacrifices to expose injustice”, and conversations throughout reveal Snowden’s hope that his actions will inspire others to come forward. The final scenes of the film seemingly vindicate this hope, as Greenwald and Snowden discuss a new, second whistleblower. During this conversation, Greenwald writes notes and sends them across the table, to evade possible surveillance. As they finish speaking, Greenwald rips them up, and the camera forces us to dwell on the piled fragments; a perfect visual summation of Citizenfour’s subject. Rarely are there comprehensive visual records of the lead-up to major world events like the Snowden disclosures. With hope, this film will continue to fuel the public dialogue over issues of level protections for whistleblowers and journalists, and of privacy versus surveillance. As the recent convictions of journalist Barrett Brown and CIA whistleblower Jeffrey Sterling demonstrate, this is a dialogue we still sorely need.

item.title: Review: Blasted
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: “It’s an hour forty-five, no interval. If you need to leave, we won’t be able to let you back in.” I nod and take my seat. As the lights die down, director Richard Wilson (yes, that Richard Wilson) laughs from the back row at some unheard joke. On stage, the middle-aged Ian and young Cate enter an unassuming, upmarket hotel room. Barely fifteen minutes hence, Ian undresses in full view of the audience, but if I listed the most graphic moments of Blasted, this scene would barely make the top ten. [youtube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vUKc573OKA0&w=560&h=315] The play’s 1995 premiere drew fierce criticism for perceived gratuity; the Daily Mail memorably described it as a “disgusting feast of filth”. Others called for the return of the censor. Built on a crux of war, violence, sex and abuse, Blasted needs virtually every trigger warning. Some conclude that the play (Sarah Kane’s first – she would write five before her suicide at 28) seeks to shock only for the sake of shocking – a problem often seen to afflict the early work of playwrights, eager to show us all how unfair the world is and how bad humans can be. How does one review a play which parades the worst humanity has to offer over the course of an hour forty-five? It truly does feel like morals disappear in the space between the audience and the stage. The acting is undeniably strong, but is at its best when characters interact. The rare solo moments are a smidgeon less convincing. Martin Marquez gives a standout performance as foul-mouthed Ian, moving from villain to victim with ease as the play progresses. Blasted leaves naturalistic theatre behind halfway through. At the play’s close, the hotel room, once pristine and pedestrian, has been utterly transformed into a hellish, expressionist space. It is gnarled and broken, reflecting the minds and bodies of the characters. The technical execution of the play is particularly deserving of praise. One audience member describes it as “technically skilled but repulsive”. Mortar explosions and staged violence feel entirely genuine; with the audience tensing visibly any time a gun is brandished. Wilson’s production does justice to Sarah Kane’s difficult source material, and is a worthy, timely adaptation of her work. With IS, the Ukraine crisis and a dozen other wars and conflicts in full swing, Blasted remains as relevant to the real world as it ever was. This is an intense, uncomfortable production. It will stick to you after you’ve left the theatre, leaves few taboos unscathed and will purge any shred of optimism from your mind. You will want to look away. Go see it anyway. This review initially appeared in the Hippo Collective in February 2015.

item.title: REVIEW: The Absence of War
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: Set in the dying days of old Labour, The Absence of War chronicles party leader George Jones and his advisors as they plot to unseat a floundering Conservative government. Playwright David Hare was invited behind the scenes of the Labour party during their failed 1992 campaign, and while the characters are fictional, many elements of the play echo real events. [youtube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DKFnbAoZM1g&w=560&h=315] This is a highly visual production. Mock speeches, Prime Minister’s Questions sessions and television interviews, are richly imagined and, arguably, the most vibrant parts of the play. It’s in these scenes that Reese Dinsdale excels playing George. The integration of televisions and video footage into the stage design is masterful; as George gives speeches, we see his own image reflected back at us from a dozen screens. It’s a great visual metaphor for the media machine these characters dote upon. The polished, reflective floor, coloured backdrops and minimal stage furnishings give the impression of moments plucked straight from history. Going into the play with no knowledge of politics, you could be forgiven for thinking it depicts real people. It’s also a rather timely production, in a way that is surely deliberate. As Labour struggle to consolidate their key message ahead of May’s election, it’s not hard to imagine scenes being re-enacted among Ed Milliband’s advisors, though there are no obvious parallels between the fictional George Jones and modern figures. For an audience in 2015, there’s nostalgia to be found in the speeches. Mainstream political figures openly shouting about old-fashioned socialism and conservativism seems distinctly unlikely in today’s political landscape, where the key distinguishing feature of the three central parties seems to be tie colour. George’s “let’s all become Tories” line now sounds less like humour and more like prophecy. We’ve lived through Alistair Campbell and the intervening generation of political satires, we all know what spin is, and the delicate curation of our leaders is well-known. There is more here than just politics. Hare has created a classic Aristotolean tragedy – a flawed hero with high hopes, an inevitable downfall and a moment of catharsis – it’s a tried and tested formula. It’s also infused with a dry cynical humour that will be instantly accessible to fans of The Thick of It. This is an entirely respectable retelling of David Hare’s work, but in 2015, the core message is hardly ground-breaking.

item.title: Review: The Casual Vacancy, Episode 1
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded:
It wouldn’t be exaggeration to claim that The Casual Vacancy, adapting JK Rowling’s first adult novel, is the most anticipated BBC drama of the year. Can it live up to the hype? [youtube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O_Myt40YHiU] The production excels in recreating the sense of small-town backstabbing and repression inherent to the novel. It’s like Hot Fuzz, only without either a sense of humour or a likeable protagonist. A pantheon of characters who are all in some way damaged and compromised may work on the page, but it’s difficult to translate to the screen.
Television audiences generally need someone to make an instant connection with. To borrow from Twin Peaks, we need our Special Agent Dale Cooper. With the early departure of Rory Kinnear’s crusader for the disenfranchised, we’re left without such a lifeline.
The acting is as strong as you’d expect, given that the cast has been a key selling point of the series, trumpeted in official publicity and boasting Michael Gambon, Rory Kinnear, Emilia Clarke and more. It’s just a shame they’re all playing such wretched characters.
Calm, detached tracking shots add to the sense of foreboding, but lend an oddly subdued tone to the whole episode, even when the plot demands otherwise.
Pacing in this first episode is also an issue, with a noticeable paucity of plot development plaguing the first half-hour. Things finally get moving toward the end, with the final scene hinting at greater things to come.
We can draw strong parallels with Broadchurch, and not only because of the prettified cinematography and nonspecific south-west accents. With this production having gotten underway soon after the ITV show’s first series, one has to wonder if there’s a relationship.
A strong, atmospheric soundtrack is provided by the band Solomon Grey; one of the few unqualified positives of this adaptation. In the midst of a backlash against austerity, the themes of social class, particularly the demonization of the working class, are timely and relevant, if a little heavy-handed.
JK Rowling’s source material is handled with care and intelligence, but given the pacing issues, one must wonder if a miniseries is really the right medium for this adaptation. It’s hard to imagine The Casual Vacancy being greenlit were it not for the cachet of its author. This isn’t to say that the show can’t improve in the remaining two hours, but at the end of this episode, I’m left simply wanting to watch Hot Fuzz again.

item.title: Photosoc Exhibition Review
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_187" align="alignright" width="200"] Image by Kunal Chopra. Used with permission.[/caption] Local favourite Bank Street Arts has given its entire ground floor over to this exhibition; five rooms, dozens of prints. You can tell by talking to people; this is an important milestone for many of them. As I examine the smeared light trails of traffic roping around dark, unfamiliar European streets, exhibiting photographers lead their guests around with half-hidden glee and un-hidden pride. The extent to which photography has been transformed in the last few decades by technology is probably unique among all the varied artforms. The utter transformation of the analogue film world to the precision of modern digital instruments had its casualties. In an age where most photographs are immaterial, with no existence outside the digital world, where printing is a gratuitous indulgence, many cry that photography is destined for commodification. Yes, this is an uninviting future. But that’s only half the story. There’s more background noise, but it forces the real gems to shine brighter to be noticed. Today’s great photographers have more competition, but the most memorable art is always born in hardship. The work presented is both more varied and of a higher artistic standard than you might expect. All of the major “families” are well-represented; landscapes, wildlife, street, sport, portraiture. This exhibition is nothing if not diverse; models rendered in high-contrast monochrome eye the camera knowingly, mice peer from beneath autumnal leaf litter, the passage of time in front of the camera lens transmutes bodies of water into flat, icy sheets. Photography is indeed a labour of love, but exhibitions like this make that labour explicit. Each image has been hand-picked from dozens or hundreds of possibilities, printed and mounted at not insignificant expense (these are students after all). Even those that start life as digital images become unique, physical objects. If any criticism is due, it is that many of these images deserve much larger prints than they were allotted. I memorise the names accompanying the images, fully expecting to come across some of them again in the years to come. This review was originally printed in Forge Press in March 2015.

item.title: On Clegg, debates and tuition fees
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: “I got the best deal I could”, said Clegg apologetically, confronted on tuition fees during last night’s debate. It’s a claim the deputy PM has repeated during countless other media appearances. Half a decade on, the bile stirred by his infamous u-turn has proven thoroughly indigestible. Clegg remains something of a national hate figure among slighted youngsters; students acting on behalf of the “Free University of Sheffield” attempted to occupy his constituency office last month, with moderate success. One of those activists, now an incoming sabbatical officer for Sheffield Students’ Union, openly states “I’m voting Labour to get revenge on Clegg”. Milliband is flirting with the student vote by promising a reduction of fees down to £6000 per annum, and it is not clear whether Clegg will even retain his Sheffield Hallam constituency seat in the face of Labour hopeful and verified dreamboat, Oliver Coppard. Of course, Clegg never meant to betray students. He was not gleefully drawing plans against us behind closed wood-panel doors. He did not willingly deceive; circumstances merely forced a compromise. In his position, any of us would have probably done the same. The intention of the new system was to create competition between universities to offer the best-value courses. That didn’t happen, of course; the vast majority of institutions immediately embarked on the upward climb, hitting the £9000 ceiling and making base camp there. Students thus receive all the debt and none of the benefit. Clegg has spoken freely about his regrets regarding tuition fees, how he wishes he’d been more careful in signing the “I will not raise fees” pledge, wishes that another outcome had been possible, wishes that the current system had been better spun (he’s a proponent of the “graduate tax” nom de guerre). But his grovelling fell largely upon deaf ears. It’s hard to point to another single event which has done more to diminish the credibility of a mainstream political party. From the words spoken by Clegg during last night’s debate, he painted himself an aged figure, out of place among optimistic representatives of the other parties. He gave the impression of having trotted out chiefly to keep up appearances, rather than as a serious attempt to engage with the electorate. Even more so than David Cameron, his words carried an air of frustration. Of the numerous factions staking a claim to victory in the debate, the Lib Dems were not one of them. Lashing out early on at his coalition superior, Clegg gave the impression of a man finished with all this; near the end of his (admittedly 5-year long) fuse. At this stage, it may well be a mercy not to vote for him, and give him a needed break before his inevitable second career as a writer/speaker/pundit/advisor/whatever. Whether things truly will be better under new management, be it Labour or someone else, remains to be seen.

item.title: Review: The King's Speech
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: A man steps out in his underwear.  Assorted household staff follow in his wake, dressing him, feeding him. There is no more fitting introduction for Prince Albert, who starts out as an impeccable stereotype of British royalty – waited on 24/7. It’s interesting that our first glimpse of Bertie should be of a man plain and unadorned. This is no doubt a deliberate choice to remind us that, outside the material trappings of the monarchy, he’s a man like any other. [youtube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mcXOT9ujzGU] The King’s Speech tells the tale of the challenged oratorical skills of Prince Albert, who was to became King George VI, and his relationship with an unconventional therapist. This is set against a backdrop of family strife, the intrusion of new technology into the traditionally private life of the king, and the growing Nazi threat. All the ingredients of a great work of theatre are present. Befitting its thematic importance, the radio microphone is central on stage. It descends menacingly from the ceiling; an adversary to be defeated. Radio presenters are placed physically higher than the play’s other characters and a large “ON AIR” sign looms over the stage action. It’s all broadly symbolic of the newfound power of the media. While the play is ostensibly about Bertie’s struggle, Australian speech therapist Lionel Logue and his wife Myrtle provide an unlikely emotional heart of the piece. Jason Donovan’s performance as Lionel is gentle, carefree, sometimes brash, but always a joy to watch. This production revolves around him. Most of those seeing this play will be reminded of the infinitely better known film adaptation, starring Colin Firth. While minor changes are made, the plot proceeds in an identical manner. We may be used to characters becoming more nuanced in translation from screen to stage, but this is not true here. Edward, Bertie’s older brother, becomes an outright bully with Nazi ties. One particularly welcome difference is Bertie’s discussion of the specific mode of King George V’s departure. He discloses to Lionel that his father’s demise was deliberately hastened so as to make the publication in the morning broadsheets as opposed to the scurrilous “evening journals”. This does well to underline Bertie’s fear of the strange new media the royals have developed. While The King’s Speech is a respectable production with true heart, a touch more innovation would have been welcome. At present, this play fails to step out of the shadow cast by its own film adaptation.

item.title: Review: Spooks - The Greater Good
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: We open on that panoramic shot of London. You know the one. The expansive, patriotic, this-is-what-we’re-fighting-for landscape recognisable from dozens of spy films. Spooks: The Greater Good hardly reinvents the spy genre, but luckily it doesn’t try to. The plot is full to bursting with dead drops, traitors, conspiracies and lone wolves. Director Bharat Nalluri, sticks to what the original TV series did best, to his merit. [youtube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=smidRILQBuk] The Greater Good preserves the anyone-can-die mentality of the series to traumatic effect. Spooks popularised this trope long before Game of Thrones was ever commissioned, achieving notoriety for brutally killing a lead character in its second episode, inundating the BBC with complaints. Riveting action scenes and a more worldwide scope (both no doubt enabled by the magnified budget) are welcome additions to the film. Harry Pearce, the main character of the series, returns and proves he’s still got some character development left in him, spending most of the film as a rogue – possibly traitorous – agent. Much of the plot heavy lifting is done by new characters, including Kit Harrington as archetypal brooding hero Whatshisname. Established characters from the series are sidelined, reduced almost to cameos. This may be a smart decision; the show has been off-air for four years after all. In particular, Sherlock alumnus Laura Pulver’s character is disappointingly underutilised. Characters tell us again and again that villain Adem Qasim is a new, charismatic threat, but such attributes are barely evident when he’s on screen. His motivations are given lip service but never fully explored. The ideological conflict between MI5 and Qasim has the seeds of compelling drama, and a little more on-screen discussion of this would have elevated The Greater Good above the reductionist us-versus-them formula. Commissioned at the height of the al-Qaeda threat, Spooks tapped into a collective cultural anxiety over the clandestine wars going on under our noses (though the first series shied away from directly examining Islamic extremism). Twelve years on, that anxiety has sublimated somewhat; the zeitgeist has moved on. It may be an appropriate time to bid the show goodbye. More than anything else, The Greater Good is one last hurrah for the fans. Were it an episode of the show, it would be an exceptional one, but even with a cinematic budget and Kit Harrington’s presence, whether it makes the cut as a standalone film is far from obvious. That said, it’s entertaining and gripping, and certainly a fit farewell for Harry Pearce.

item.title: Review: Jurassic World
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: The original Jurassic Park soared because, with all the effects stripped away, it was a simple story with a simple moral. Jurassic World takes the central “life will find a way” maxim and re-treads it with better effects, new characters and an original, completely insane plot thread involving the use of dinosaurs as weapons. [youtube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RFinNxS5KN4] Some elements of the plot stick too close to the path carved out by the original, particularly children going missing in the park while escaped dinos wreak havoc, but Colin Trevorrow should be praised for at least seeking out an original story, in an ocean of straight remakes and reboots. Jurassic World successfully explores the intelligence of the velociraptors to an extent we never really saw in the original run of films, but they’re convincingly portrayed as the same vicious killers we were introduced to in 1993. Most characters rightfully regard the idea of using velociraptors on the battlefield as bonkers. It’s said that sci-fi and fantasy audiences will tolerate the impossible for the sake of a good story, but not the improbable. People will willingly buy into the idea of resurrecting dinosaurs from extinction, but it’s harder to forgive the wilful stupidity inherent in using thermal sensors to guard the paddock of a hybrid dinosaur designed to be able to hide from those same sensors. If you’re willing to forgive the massive levels of human stupidity needed to drive the plot, you’re in for an entertaining ride. It’s nice to finally have an in-universe explanation for the inaccuracy of some of the dinos presented at last (especially the preposterously large velociraptors, which were closer to chicken-sized in reality). It’s all down to hybridisation, according to Dr Wu (BD Wong, reprising his role from the original). It’s unfortunate that the climax of the film should take the form of a monster vs. monster battle more worthy of a Power Rangers episode or Godzilla flick, but it’s hard to think of another satisfying conclusion given the nature of the plot. All that said, the film does show a certain self-aware intelligence as it plays out, wisely keeping the overplayed T. rex in its back pocket until the final scenes. It’s more of a worthy successor to the original than either of the interim sequels. In the final analysis, Jurassic World does what it sets out to and leaves the audience wanting more. Just enough plot threads are left open (what happens to the park now? What about the missing embryos?) to invite more sequels, which are now all but inevitable, given record-breaking box office takings.

item.title: Review: Pioneer
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: A couple, Oskar and Imke, try to eke out a living on the surface of Mars. After the mission’s elderly financier falls ill, a new mission director steers the next mission to the red planet. A pair of Russian brothers, tracing their rocket scientist father’s legacy, drive across their homeland in an antique car. [caption id="attachment_205" align="aligncenter" width="620"] Photo: Richard Davenport[/caption] The Studio theatre, Sheffield, might not be an obvious setting for a weighty, imaginative exploration of our place in the universe – a topic generally reserved for deep-pocketed Hollywood studios, but the theatre company Curious Directive have certainly made a go of it. The company’s unique selling point is the guidance they take from real scientists in shaping their productions. Characters decry the historic (for them) Mars One mission failure, noting that it did not try to recruit scientists. This is all too similar to real-world objections to the mission, which aims to scoop up a handful of normal people and send them on a one-way trip to the red planet. While it’s not entirely like any other science fiction work, Pioneer has no shortage of inspirations. The set design is a descendent of 2001: A Space Odyssey. The philosophical undertones and glorification of the human drive to explore would be well at home in Interstellar, but the plot owes most to the seventies conspiracy thriller Capricorn One, with a little of Duncan Jones’ modern classic Moon thrown in. As the play progresses, the Russian brothers end up driving, breakneck, through the deserted Aral Sea, and our astronaut Imke, alone and desperate, prepares to exit her habitat and step onto the surface of Mars. The link between these stories eventually becomes satisfyingly clear. For a play swimming in such big ideas, the sets are endearingly low-tech. Pioneer’s weakness is how it attempts to do so many things at once. It’s admirably ambitious for such a small production, in terms of sound, visuals and sets. A technical hitch here and a rickety set piece there did not, however, detract from an otherwise cohesive, well-thought-out production. With a bigger budget, or more a pared down aesthetic, this would have been a perfect self-contained little play. It’s not quite there, but it certainly lends a little intrigue and grandeur to a Wednesday evening, and makes one interested to see what Curious Directive will create next.

item.title: Review: Terminator Genisys
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: The core problem with the Terminator franchise is that the original movie, a mid-80s B-movie, was never meant to be the cornerstone of a multimillion dollar franchise. It was conceived as a small, self-contained movie. The core paradox; Kyle Reese going back in time and fathering John Connor, who will eventually send him back in time, is so neatly resolved that sequels aren’t called for. All the dramatic threads are put to bed by the ending credits. [youtube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rGSxss7gWak&w=560&h=315] 1997’s Terminator 2: Judgement Day succeeded through sheer audacity; altering the formula just enough to remain interesting. Where the original film was preoccupied with fate and inevitability, T2 introduced the idea that nuclear war and the rise of the machines might be averted. That, along with pitching Arnie as the good guy, was the key to its dramatic success. But by then, the genie was out of the bottle and the stage was set for additional disappointing instalments. The franchise has since been a succession of failed attempts to reignite the magic of the original film. Perhaps inspired by the recent Star Trek reboot, Terminator Genisys attempts to resolve this terminal franchise syndrome by taking a sledgehammer to the events of the original film and positing an alternative timeline. Escaping the core paradox of the original film necessitates a degree of disrespect towards it that is likely to alienate old fans. This attempt can’t easily be described as a success. The move from the events of the original film to the new timeline is haphazard, like something out of a badly written fanfiction. The decision to update Sarah Connor from a frightened, helpless young woman to a smart person in control of their own future is a wise one, but the film assumes that since the audience already know that Sarah and Reese get together, it doesn’t need to waste time on extravagances like believable dialogue or chemistry. The final kiss between the two is almost laughable in its out-of-nowhereness. 1984’s Terminator had an obsession with industrial machinery and grit. You can see it in the future war scenes, in the hydraulics and joints of the Terminator endoskeletons, in the automated factory in which the climactic battle of the film occurs. Everything is heavy, practical, functional and solid. 2015’s Terminator Genisys substitutes this obsession with a modern, sleek, superhero-esque aesthetic. The fight scenes are outrageous, more at home in an Avengers movie. Seeing two computer-generated terminators punch each other for ten minutes sucks all the threat and emotional gravity out of a scene. The biggest problem with Genisys is not that it replaces the events of the original movie, but that it replaces the aesthetic as well. There are major problems with Genisys which prevent it from being regarded as a worthy successor to the franchise. But, now the alternate timeline has been established, however awkwardly, the scene is set for subsequent sequels to improve upon.

item.title: Bill Bailey on Limboland
item.dc:creator: jhackett1
item.content:encoded: Having performed at Wembley a few years back, what new challenges are there in making new shows? It’s hard to find a new challenge. I’ve performed in situations I never dreamed I would. I’ve been on stage with an orchestra at the Albert Hall. I’ve been to Sonisphere and performed in front of thousands of metalheads. I focus on refinement and more interesting subjects nowadays. That’s what Limboland is; a bit more honest, a bit more personal and reflective. I decided not to go down the visual route with this show. Many of my past shows have been visual spectacles, but I made a conscious decision not to do that here. On the first night I was really nervous, but there’s no one in the audience thinking “oh, I wish he’d had a big screen behind him.” If it’s a funny show, you don’t need it. What will people enjoy most about the new show? There’s some funny personal stories, maybe a bit more revealing than in my other shows. Lots of music, as per, and some good mashups chucked into the mix. I like a mashup, me; Miley Cyrus with Kraftwerk, Kurt Weill with Happy Birthday. There’s some big fixed setpieces, but lots of time in between where I can just go off the rails, and I quite like that. Tinselworm, Qualmpeddler and now Limboland – what’s the Bill Bailey show name formula? I like to make up a new word. Comedy is quite mercurial – you never know where it’s going to go, so you’re making a rod for your own back by making everything fit under a title. I thought Tinselworm would be great because it’s like a cheap worm, rather than a silkworm, which is the ultimate – a few notches down the league table of worms you get a tinselworm; the shiny, gaudy version that wants to be a silkworm. You’re known for bringing obscure instruments on stage – any more in this show? I’ve got a new theremin! They’re devilishly hard things to play, some nights it sounds like a seal trapped under a wardrobe. I’ve found a theremini; it’s a smaller, modern digital version. By some kind of bizarre technological sorcery, instead of a smooth glissando of notes, you get a proper scale with neat little steps. It’s a very complex piece of kit, but it makes all the difference live. You’re a well-known conservationist. Where does that interest come from? I grew up in quite a rural part of England, and mum and dad were into the outdoors, so I was exposed to it from an early age. Britain is only a small country, and I find myself thinking how much more of it we can concrete over. We really need to keep the wild green spaces, because once they’re gone, that’s it, they aren’t coming back. Conservation is in the public consciousness now, while it was just a sort of crackpot idea a few years ago. That’s a very good thing. What other projects do you have in the works? I’m hoping to do a successor to my nature show Jungle Hero, hopefully in the new year. I’m also writing a comedy sketch show for the BBC, and I’m also toying with the idea of doing a paddleboarding documentary. There’s quite a few things on the horizon. This interview was originally published in Exposed magazine in July 2015.
